events.name: SDJUG Meeting (www.sdjug.org)

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description: Speaker: Svetlin Stanchev, Objectist Software, Inc. Title: "Retaining state between configuration changes in Android" Abstract: Svetlin will describe the need to explicitly handle configuration changes in Android (e.g. a device orientation change). The framework-provided call back methods will be compared. Using a simple demo program, retaining state, using fragments, will be reviewed. Note: Basic knowledge about Android activity life-cycle will not be covered. Audience participation is welcome. Speaker: Erik Colban, Drametry Title: "A Case against Finite State Machines" Abstract: In this talk, Erik will go through different approaches; classical FSM approach, FSM using the State Pattern, using coroutines as an alternative to FSM and using threads as an alternative to FSM. He will highlight the pros and cons of each approach and illustrate each with a demo -- a small app where the user draws ellipses and polylines on a window pane.

events.name: First Formal Meetup!

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/b/0/2/e/event_63525102.jpegI'm happy to announce that our first formal meetup will take place on Wednesday, November 16 at the Bridgepoint Education offices in North County near the 15-56 interchange!

Some of you have been to our two previous informal meetups at Karl Strauss. We may still do more of those but I wanted to get us on track with some more formal meetups where we can dig into some technical topics as a group.  

 

 

Group member and Android enthusiast Jack Holt will be presenting on these Android development topics:

  Using the MapActivity  Using web services within an Android app Interfacing with Facebook using the Android APIs  Jack has been a computer professional/enthusiast since he first programmed a Honeywell mini-computer in 1981.  He has done everything from operating a computer room full of servers to co-founding smartphone app development startups.  He became a web app developer in 1996 when he showed his boss what web apps could do.  He first programmed mobile devices (PocketPCs) in 2002.  He started development of the Reveal Reader for Android in 2008 on Android 1.1.  Since then he has actually made money as a contractor developer for Android and co-founder of ZapMe.  However, he still makes most of his money as a Web Application Developer for SAIC.

 

Agenda:

6:00-6:30 - greet and meet; Bridgepoint will be catering food and drink for us!

6:30-6:45 - Bill Wixted - ADG (Android Developer Group) housekeeping; introduce the Bridgepoint folks; introduce Jack Holt

6:45-7:45- Jack Holt - presents the topics above

7:45-8:00 - Q&A

 

Given that this is our first formal meetup will be winging it in terms of the format somewhat.  I want to promote a free form and lively interchange of ideas and expertise.  I will be soliciting ideas from you all on how best to organize our meetups, potential topics, etc. 

 

Here are driving directions:

Bridgepoint is located on the southeast corner of the 15 and 56 interchange.  If you're heading eastbound on the 56 take the first exit after the 15.  That road is Sabre Springs Parkway.

If you're traveling on the 15 take the Ted Williams Parkway exit heading east.  Exit (almost immediately) and turn right on Sabre Springs Parkway.

Head south on Sabre Springs Parkway a very short distance.  Take the second right which is Evening Creek Road.  Travel a short distance.  You will see some large buildings and a large driveway to turn into on the right.  

We will be meeting in the middle building which is known as the Ashford building.  Park anywhere on the street or in the lot.  Come inside the Ashford building and up to the fourth floor. Exit the elevators and look for the conference room labeled Leadership Room.

 

Will see you all soon!

 

Bill Wixted

San Diego - Android Developers Group Organizer
events.how_to_find_us: We will be in the fourth floor conference room.  Walk into the Ashford building and take the elevator up.  See the driving directions in the meeting notice.

events.name: February Meetup - Android NDK/ARM development and UI Design with Fragments

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
Our February 15 meeting now has two excellent speakers scheduled.  You will not want to miss this meeting!  This is also the first meeting where we will be co-hosting with the San Diego - Google Technology Users Group.

First, I'm very happy to announce that we will have Matthew DuPuy, Developer Evangelist at ARM and accomplished mountain climber, presenting on the Android NDK (Native Development Kit) for ARM, DS-5 Community Edition (debugging and performance analysis tools for Eclipse) and open source NEON SIMD libraries.

ARM designs the technology that lies at the heart of a myriad of devices including mobile phones, tablets, digital media players and many others.  Their low-cost, low-power consumption microprocessors and microcontrollers have become dominant in the mobile and embedded electronics market.  As of 2009, ARM processors accounted for approximately 90% of all embedded 32-bit RISC processors.

Matt is a computer engineer who's been working with embedded software and system integration for over a decade. He started using Linux in college in the late 90's and has more than a few lines of code in the USB stacks and drivers as well as many consumer devices from iPods to TVs to navigation systems. After a sabbatical in 2009 to climb Mt. Everest, he returned to engineering contracting until the summer of 2011. He has a keen interest in Android and Google's 'release first and iterate fast' designs and was hired at ARM as a developer evangelist to both improve ARM's tools, libraries and compiler technologies as they relate to Android internally and to solicit developer input from independent applications developers as well as major device manufacturers. He is very interested to hear what developers consider as a priority to get the best performance and user experience from ARM powered devices and is happy to share some of the tools and projects ARM has been working on.

 

Our second speaker is David Sainte-Claire, who heads up the San Diego Google Technology Users Group (SD-GTUG).  David will be presenting to us on developing Android user interfaces using Fragments. Fragments were introduced in Android 3.0 primarily to provide more dynamic and flexible user interface designs on larger screens like tablets.

 

 

Agenda:

6:00-6:30 - greet and meet; Bridgepoint will be catering food and drink for us!

6:30-6:50 - Bill Wixted - ADG (Android Developer Group) housekeeping; group member introductions; announcements about employment opportunities; introduction of Matt DuPuy

6:50-7:45- Matt DuPuy from ARM

7:45-8:00 - Q&A

8:00-8:45 - David St. Claire presents fragments

 

 

Here are driving directions: Bridgepoint is located on the southeast corner of the 15 and 56 interchange. If you're heading eastbound on the 56 take the first exit that is immediately after the ramp to 15 northbound. That road is Sabre Springs Parkway. If you're traveling on the 15 take the Ted Williams Parkway exit heading east. Exit (almost immediately) and turn right on Sabre Springs Parkway. Head south on Sabre Springs Parkway a very short distance. Take the second right which is Evening Creek Road. Travel a very short distance and turn into the third driveway you see on your right.  We will be meeting in the Ashford building which is the one in the middle with the "Ashford.edu" sign on it. Park anywhere on the street or in the lot. Come inside the Ashford building and up to the fourth floor. Exit the elevators and look for the conference room labeled Leadership Room.

Will see you all soon! Bill Wixted San Diego - Android Developers Group Organizer

events.description:
I'm very happy to announce that we will have Norman McEntire of Servin presenting to us on developing for the Android 4.0 platform code name "Ice Cream Sandwich" or "ICS" for short.

Norman McEntire, M.S., MCSE, founded Servin Corporation in 1995 to provide computer training, consulting, and software development with a focus on Android, iOS, and Linux. With 25+ years of experience, he has designed both hardware and software at all levels, from embedded Linux to enterprise software. His training clients include Dell, HP, IBM, Intel, NCR, and Qualcomm.

Normal is also an instructor with UCSD Extension and has taught numerous courses on Android, Objective-C and iOS programming.  I took his Introduction to Android Programming class in 2011 and was very impressed with the quality of the courses and Norman's dedication to his students.  Norman is an excellent instructor and I'm sure this meeting will be very educational for anyone who is interested in developing for Ice Cream Sandwich.  Norman will guide us through several live-coding examples to show us how to make the most of this exciting new platform.

events.name: April Meetup - Speech Recognition and Text-To-Speech with Android

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
I'm very happy to announce that we will have Wolf Paulus of Intuit (and the San Diego Android Developers Group) presenting to us on Android's speech recognition and text-to-speech capabilities.

Wolf Paulus is an internationally experienced software developer and innovator, focusing on Android, embedded/mobile devices, and open source technologies. In his daytime job he helps to accelerate the discovery and adoption of emerging mobile technologies. Before joining Intuit, he was the Sr. Mobile Architect at HP, developing solutions, to deliver a compelling mobile print experience and a Distinguished Engineer at Motorola, working on the Google Android platform. 

Wolf will be presenting a close look at Android's Speech-To-Text (STT) and Text-To-Speech (TTS) capabilities to write and deploy a simple app that is repeating back what we are speaking into the device, utilizing STT and TTS.  Android uses Google's Speech-To-Text engine in the cloud but has Text-To-Speech capabilities baked right into Android since Android 2.0 (Donut), using SVOX Pico with six language packages (US and UK English, German, French, Italian and Spanish).

events.name: Android Code Jam at Kyocera

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
Join us for a laptop (tablets too, if you can compile code on it!) event at Kyocera's offices in UTC on Thursday, May 3 (6:00-8:00).  This event will be interactive and involves code development, and limited to 12 people.  For those without a portable development machine, I'll post the code after the event.  If you really want to come without a computer to see other people type and mouse around, we can probably have some chairs set up too.

For this meeting, I wanted to introduce people to the Google Code Jams, if you have not heard of them.  The specific Problem for the night will be "All Your Base".
http://code.google.com/codejam/contest/189252/dashboard#s=p0

Before the event, be sure to have a programming environment ready to go on your computer.  (Many thanks to Dave for the previous laptop meeting where we helped everyone install Eclipse on the systems.)  If you need help installing Eclipse, I am sure a USB drive will be floating around with the install image.  However, you'll be behind the power curve for the evening!

I am looking for participants to create an Android program solution for the Code Jam problem, but any code environment will work - so long as you are writing code.  For the meeting:

You can have the entire program written, and help others You can have a basic input/output framework set up (EditBox & TextBox, with a Go button), and code a solution to the problem at the event You have your IDE ready to go and code everything at the event Here is the contents of the link above:

This contest is open for practice. You can try every problem as many times as you like, though we won't keep track of which problems you solve. Read the Quick-Start Guide to get started.

Small input
8 points
Large input
15 points
Problem

In A.D. 2100, aliens came to Earth. They wrote a message in a cryptic language, and next to it they wrote a series of symbols. We've come to the conclusion that the symbols indicate a number: the number of seconds before war begins!

Unfortunately we have no idea what each symbol means. We've decided that each symbol indicates one digit, but we aren't sure what each digit means or what base the aliens are using. For example, if they wrote "ab2ac999", they could have meant "[masked]" in base 10 -- exactly one year -- or they could have meant "[masked]" in base 6 --[masked] seconds, or about four and a half days. We are sure of three things: the number is positive; like us, the aliens will never start a number with a zero; and they aren't using unary (base 1).

Your job is to determine the minimum possible number of seconds before war begins.

Input

The first line of input contains a single integer, T. T test cases follow. Each test case is a string on a line by itself. The line will contain only characters in the 'a' to 'z' and '0' to '9' ranges (with no spaces and no punctuation), representing the message the aliens left us. The test cases are independent, and can be in different bases with the symbols meaning different things.

Output

For each test case, output a line in the following format:

Case # X: V Where X is the case number (starting from 1) and V is the minimum number of seconds before war begins.

Limits

1 ≤ T ≤ 100
The answer will never exceed 1018

Small dataset

1 ≤ the length of each line < 10

Large dataset

1 ≤ the length of each line < 61

Sample

Input 

Output 
3
[masked]
cats
zig
Case #1: 201
Case #2: 75
Case #3: 11

events.name: Android project meetup

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
A project came across my desk the other day that I thought would be great for us to work on. I already have the project spec'd out. I have the project broken up into about 8 10-hour tasks. If anyone is interested in getting some real world experience on a production ready android app, then bring your laptop and let's get work.

The goal of this meeting will be to get introduced to the project, get everyone setup on the repository and assign tasks.

ALL SKILL LEVELS WELCOME!

We can meet at my office. There are plenty of paid parking in the area $3-$7. The Padres are away that day.

Bring a couple of dollars if you want to go in on a pizza.

I know coming downtown is a pain, so I'll also setup a G+ Hangout for those that can't make it.

If you are planning on joining the G+ Hangout, make sure you follow me so I can invite you to the Hangout.

 

Prep work:

If you haven't already, try to get your dev environment setup.   We will be using Eclipse.  Here is a tutorial to get your environment setup.  We will also be using the Google Code Repository and SVN for version control.  You can find a tutorial on how to set it up here.  I'll give you the access to the project during the meetup.  Just get the Svn Repository Explorer installed for now.

events.name: Kyocera Code Jam

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
Join us for a laptop (tablets too, if you can compile code on it!) event at Kyocera's offices in UTC on Thursday, Sept 13 (6:00-8:00).  This event will be interactive and involves code development, and limited to 12 people.  For those without a portable development machine, I'll post the code after the event.  If you really want to come without a computer to see other people type and mouse around, we can probably have some chairs set up too.

We will be reviewing the problem proposed at:

http://code.google.com/codejam/contest/544101/dashboard#s=p0

People are encouraged to attempt to solve the program before the meeting.  The meeting should be walking through the solutions of the attendees, or debugging of their programs.  Any language / platform for a solution.  Last time we had Java / C++ / Python solutions.

Thursday 13 Sep 2012

Kyocera Communications

9520 Towne Centre Drive

San Diego, CA 92121

Limit of 12 attendees

Problem

In the exciting game of Join-K, red and blue pieces are dropped into an N-by-N table. The table stands up vertically so that pieces drop down to the bottom-most empty slots in their column. For example, consider the following two configurations:

     - Legal Position -             .......           .......           .......           ....R..           ...RB..           ..BRB..           .RBBR..    - Illegal Position -             .......           .......           .......           .......    Bad -> ..BR...           ...R...           .RBBR.. In these pictures, each '.' represents an empty slot, each 'R' represents a slot filled with a red piece, and each 'B' represents a slot filled with a blue piece. The left configuration is legal, but the right one is not. This is because one of the pieces in the third column (marked with the arrow) has not fallen down to the empty slot below it.

A player wins if they can place at least K pieces of their color in a row, either horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. The four possible orientations are shown below:

       - Four in a row -        R   RRRR    R   R      R          R     R      R         R       R      R        R         R In the "Legal Position" diagram at the beginning of the problem statement, both players had lined up two pieces in a row, but not three.

As it turns out, you are right now playing a very exciting game of Join-K, and you have a tricky plan to ensure victory! When your opponent is not looking, you are going to rotate the board 90 degrees clockwise onto its side. Gravity will then cause the pieces to fall down into a new position as shown below:

     - Start -        .......      .......      .......      ...R...      ...RB..      ..BRB..      .RBBR..    - Rotate -       .......      R......      BB.....      BRRR...      RBB....      .......      .......    - Gravity -        .......      .......      .......      R......      BB.....      BRR....      RBBR... Unfortunately, you only have time to rotate once before your opponent will notice.

All that remains is picking the right time to make your move. Given a board position, you should determine which player (or players!) will have K pieces in a row after you rotate the board clockwise and gravity takes effect in the new direction.

Notes

You can rotate the board only once. Assume that gravity only takes effect after the board has been rotated completely. Only check for winners after gravity has finished taking effect.

There are a group of companies that are different, more profitable and sustainable than most other businesses. They lead by delivering extraordinary customer experiences and user experiences, yet they account for just five percent of all businesses worldwide. These leading businesses develop their customer experience strategy and user experience strategy beginning with very effective personas.

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
Hello Android Group,

I'm very excited to announce the details of our next meetup on Wednesday, April 16 at Coleman College!  This is one meeting you will not want to miss!

Matthew DuPuy is a Software Engineer at ARM.  ARM is a multinational semiconductor and software design firm that dominates the market for processors embedded in smart phones and tablets.  Their technology lies at the core of 95% of the world's smartphones and a sizable share of digital TVs and set-top boxes.  Licensees of ARM's technology include Apple (iPhone/iPad), Samsung, Nokia, HTC and Sony Ericsson.

Matthew will share his expertise in performing application and systems level analysis on Android apps and platforms using tools from Google, ARM, AT&T and others.  He will explain how to find bottlenecks in both SDK and NDK activities and demonstrate different approaches to fixing those bottlenecks and better utilize platform technologies and APIs. 

In summary, if you want to develop an Android app that runs quickly and efficiently you must attend this meeting!

Please note the venue change for our group!  This meeting will be at Coleman College in Kearny Mesa near the 163 and Balboa.  Rod Weiss and the super nice people at Coleman have offered us their excellent facilities for this and future meetups.  We will be meeting in Hopper Hall at Coleman.  So don't show up at Dell because no one will be there!

Here is the agenda:

5:30 - 6:15 - networking with food & refreshments brought to you by ARM!

6:15 - 6:30 - general announcements and introductions

6:30 - 7:30 - Matthew DuPuy presents

7:30 - 8:00 - Q&A

I'm very pleased to announce that we will have Sanjay Kalyanasundaram of Mocana presenting to the group for our May meetup!  He will be discussing mobile application security and introducing us to Mocana's Mobile App Protection (MAP) solution.

Sanjay runs Mocana’s Developer Platform.  He is a mobile product guy who loves building mobile services that delight customers.  He has done stints at device manufacturers, managed customer apps, built services for wireless carriers and most recently has been focused on enterprise developer platforms. 

Mocana's Mobile App Protection (MAP) allows developers to make their app enterprise ready in seconds.  MAP allows Android and iOS developers to wrap their mobile app in a security layer, using a simple point and click interface. The entire process takes only a matter of seconds, saving the developers months of time of coding.

MAP allows developers to focus all of their creative time and energy on the quality of their app, without worrying about coding security features.  Mocana provides a free tool kit for developers via their Mobile Developer Platform.

Group member Ryan Bradley of Integrated Associates will be providing food and drink this month.

We are meeting at the usual place (Dell Software conference center) at 9540 Towne Centre Drive.  If you use Google Maps to find us beware that we are one building to the south of the building they point to.

events.name: RxJava and Reactive Programming for Android Apps

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
I'm very happy to announce that we will have Christopher Perry from Sony Electronics presenting to the group for our October meetup!

Christopher is an Android guru who has been writing Android applications since 2010. He is currently with Sony Electronics where he is the tech lead and architect for the Info-Eye camera application. Christopher is the author of mooLa, one of the top selling finance apps for Android. While contracting for Intuit at Pivotal Labs he was involved in updates to the Robolectric testing framework which included adding fragment support. At Fandango, Christopher worked with a small team to build and launch three applications from scratch in one and a half years time. Christopher will give an introduction to Reactive programming using RxJava. Although it's a Java library, it has applications in Android, specifically for processing and transforming data in the background. It nicely replaces things like AsyncTask, Loaders, and (God forbid!) rolling your own Thread code. The introduction will include a few practical examples.

We will have food and drink this time thanks to Kathleen Krapfl and Outsource Technical!

Speaker: Ryan Milbourne
Title: Bitcoin 101: Beyond the Price Abstract: This talk is geared to an audience who is new to Bitcoin. We are going to cover the origins and historical context of Bitcoin in the digital currency space, how the Bitcoin protocol works on a technical level, what problems Bitcoin solves, and potential markets that Bitcoin can disrupt. Q&A is encouraged throughout the talk and we will touch on smart contracts and Crypto-Currency 2.0 projects if time permits.

Speaker Bio: Ryan is a java developer and a certified crypto-currency consultant by the Digital Currency Institute and has given Bitcoin talks at So Cal Code Camp. He is primarily interested in how Bitcoin can serve the 6 billion under banked of the world and how smart contracts can reduce the friction in conducting business and creating worker owned cooperatives.

Bio:
Norman McEntire founded Servin Corporation in 1995 to focus on leading-edge software technology, providing software training, software consulting, and software development to technology focused clients. With 30+ years of experience in computer engineering, he has designed and built hardware at the chip, board, and system-level, as well as written software at the device-driver, system-software, and application software level (both command-line and GUI apps). Since 2007 Norman has focused his attention on three software technologies: Android, iOS, and Embedded Linux. Norman has used his unique “show it live and in action” training style to train thousands of software developers in major technology companies, including: Avaya, Broadcom, Cubic, Dell, Fidelity, HP, IBM, Intel, Intuit, Motorola, NCR, Qualcomm, Wells Fargo, and more. events.name: Wearables, the Internet of Things and Micro Applications

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
I'm very happy to announce that we will have Wolf Paulus of Intuit (and the San Diego Android Developers Group) presenting to us on Wearables, Internet of Things and Micro Applications.

Wolf Paulus is an internationally experienced software developer and innovator, focusing on Android, embedded/mobile devices, and open source technologies. In his daytime job he helps to accelerate the discovery and adoption of emerging mobile technologies. Before joining Intuit, he was the Sr. Mobile Architect at HP, developing solutions, to deliver a compelling mobile print experience and a Distinguished Engineer at Motorola, working on the Google Android platform. 

Here's a description from Wolf on his presentation:

Micro Service / Micro Applications, and "the data finds you" are the next big platform shift and wearables and the IoT are right in he middle of it. If you think about it, it also means you have to push information to your user, who may receive it on a very constrained device, like an Android Wear watch, which he cannot really type on, but can speak to, since it has a microphone and Google has an incredible speech recognizer …

Long story short, I will cover some very exciting technologies like “Wearables”, "Push Notifications”, “Speech Recognition” how to make sense of those uttered commands etc. and if there is still time, I may talk a little about "Emotional Prosody” or how we can synthesis text into speech, with and emotional state attached.

Ryan Costigan and the folks at TEKSystems will be providing food and drink for us.

events.name: SDJUG Cross Post: Voice User Interfaces

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
Cross post from the San Diego Java User's Group
New meeting location: ResMed!
Networking and food at 6:30pm

Speaker: Wolf Paulus

Title: Voice User Interfaces

Abstract: ‎You don't have to put you ear on the ground, and still, can literally hear it coming.
‎ We are at the beginning of a paradigm shift for how information gets distributed to end users. Instead of users requesting (pulling) data from servers and services, information is pushed to users' mobile devices, just at the right time. These push notifications can even be actionable, i.e. allowing a direct response. However, if they arrive on wearable device, like a smart watch, a user can only use gestures and voice to interact.

You don't have to put you ear on the ground, and still, can literally hear it coming. The broad introduction of Voice User Interfaces. I will cover some basic speech recognition ideas and how to implement them on mobile devices, will give an overview of how push notifications work and what it takes to implement them in Java on the server side (Push) in an Android mobile app (Receive), and give an overview of Android Wear, how it works and what you can do with it.

You will get glimpse of what could be the next big thing in UX and how it all fits together.

Bio: ‎Wolf Paulus is a photographer, hiker, hacker, technologist based in Ramona, California. He is currently working on Android projects, occasionally speak at developer conferences, and work on open source projects (Swixml, HessDroid, …). You can contact him by email at [masked] and can read much more at http://wolfpaulus.com/about.
Twitter: @wolfpaulus
G+: http://wolfpaulus.com/+

events.name: DEVELOPMENT CHALLENGE $1500 CASH REWARD (NO PHYSICAL LOCATION!)

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
A local start-up has run into a challenge with the development of their Android App. They are offering a CASH REWARD of up to $1500 if someone can find a solution. Please see the details below! Here is what they would like the app to do: 1) User is on an active phone call2) During active call user opens the app *****(#3 is where we are having difficulty)***** 3) The app then plays a pre-programmed/recorded audio message on a continuous loop through the phone so that the user at the other end of the call hears the message. (Playing audio loud enough on the speaker so that the microphone picks it up is not a valid solution)4) Needs to work on most major phone models and Android operating systems 4.1 and newer5) Needs to be accomplished without rooting the phone.6) Cannot compromise the ability to have the app listed in the Google Play store. Total reward offered $1500 -Solution for Android 4.1 and above, full reward of $1500-Solution for Android 5.0 and above only, partial reward of $1000-In the case that a solution if found for 5.0 and above only, the remaining $500 will be offered for a solution for[masked] Terms and conditions -We will accept entries through Midnight December 2nd. We may extend the time period should we not have a winning solution by that date.-Must provide the original source code as part of the submission.-Ideally, if any libraries are used to solve the problem, these libraries would be open source and have no restrictions with being used in a commercial app.-In the instance that the solution uses licensed code we will need to review that licensing agreement before deciding whether or not to approve the solution and this decision will be made at our sole discretion.-Submissions will be posted as comments in the Meetup Event- in the order they come in and we will make every attempt to review the submission within 24hrs during the business week. -We will also post the results when we have accepted a solution.-The winner will need to assign the copywrite so that we have unlimited use of the code.-The cash reward will be issued to the first successful/approved solution or partial solution only. Total reward to be issued $1500. Should no solution be approved no reward will be paid. -Submissions can be made to Andre Doucette, Product Director at

[masked]

<a>[masked] ext. 747</a>

  ___________________________________________________________________ 

Feedback so far:

 #1) One developers investigation results: The few hacky tricks I had in mind will not work. This shows how the Android RIL PDK is organized:

http://www.netmite.com/android/mydroid/development/pdk/docs/telephony.html

 Essentially explaining why this is all you can access publically:

http://developer.android.com/reference/android/telephony/package-summary.html

 My explanation:  when you pick up a phone call the microphone is routed directly to a codec connected to the baseband via 

SlimBus

.  There is no way to communicate with it in 

AOSP

. There is a rooted solution, but that is equivalent to no solution in my opinion and would be worth far more than this bounty to develop (requires some heavy kernel mods and AOSP mods) and even then might be rejected by the baseband codec as these are very time sensitive.  I've done some mods like this before, the end result will be that it works on one device type and that is it.  Some of Qualcomm's chipsets allow audio injection and support an API for it but this would require rooting as well. We discussed a custom dialer app.  You will still be at the mercy of the vendors firmware, so all the above issues would still exist, solving nothing. I don't consider a solution that plays audio out the speaker phone at a high enough volume to be picked up by the mic a valid solution.  I've played with apps that do that and it is flaky at best.  Add in existence of headsets, different fidelity of mics/speakers, different acoustic echo cancellation and this solution will never be a general one.  The best version of this method I could come up with was requiring the user to have a Bluetooth headset, then place it on the phone and have the phone start pumping out music.  I figured this would be best because you can physically place the Bluetooth headset mic on your phones speaker giving the best chance of clear transfer. A few solutions can be derived if you allow each end point to call into an external system which routes the call together.  At that point you have full control over the audio stream between both ends.  This solution doesn't sound ideal for your end game but if you are interested in exploring it let me know. “(CORRECT WE ARE ALREADY AWARE OF THIS OPTION HOWEVER IT IS NOT IDEAL, WE WANT THE APP TO PLAY THE MESSAGE WITOUT A 3RDPARTY)” Sorry!  Hope my explanations help in your search.  I'd love to hear if anyone can solve it in a legit generic non-rooted manner.  #2) Discussion from posting the question on Google + Android Developers Group: 

Andre Doucette

Hi! We're trying to build an IVR-like system, which will provide verbal instructions to the other side of a phone call. The problem we're having is in playing the verbal instructions (a pre-recorded sound file) on the outgoing audio stream so that the other person is able to hear it. There seems to be no standard way of doing this, but has anyone found ways to accomplish this? Are there any libraries we can use? What about replacing the dialer, or dropping to JNI-land?﻿ 

Boardies IT Solutions

 There are services that do this such as Aculab Cloud and Twilio are the ones I know of but there are several available. I personally use Twilio has a simple and straight forward api and is pretty good value for money. ﻿

Andre Doucette

Twilio is excellent. We've used it for other projects as well. The issue is that we want this to work without having the call to originate at a server phone number. That is, we want this to work on a regular cell-to-cell phone call, and then our app will take over the call. I believe Twilio would only work if the original phone call was to a Twilio number. Is there a way to "hand off" an existing call to Twilio?﻿ Boardies IT SolutionsNot that I know of. The only way I can think of doing this would be if phone a does the outbound call as normal. You listen for a phone state change listener to say that the outbound call has been answered and then cell a plays an audio file, file being embedded into the app. The only thing i'm not sure of though is whether the android API allows an audio file to be played through to a call. 

The only other way is that phone a outdials to twilio and the twilio outdials to phone b passing the CLI of phone a, although this would require twilio having phone a CLI as a verified number which I guess there could be lots of CLIs you're calling from so this may not be suitable. Hope this helps though. ﻿ 

Andre Doucette

Our attempts to play an audio file on the outgoing stream has so far been unsuccessful. It seems there is no obvious/standard way to do this. What about replacing the dialer? Would that give us access to underlying APIs we can't as a regular app?﻿ 

Boardies IT Solutions

I don't think so, if its available in the API then you should be able to do it, replacing the dialer won't give you any extra API as to make a different dialer, you'll still be using the same public API to create the dialer if you see what I mean. From having a quick Google it doesn't look as if the android API supports sending an audio stream through the call. The only alternative would be to play the audio file loud enough so that the microphone can pick up the audio but quality would be probably be very poor and you'd have little control over the volume as different devices may pick up the audio better than others.﻿

events.description:

See www.sdjug.org for location and updates

Combined San Diego Java User’s Group and San Diego Robotics Open House

San Diego Java User’s Group, IEEE San Diego Section and San Diego Robotics Club are co-hosting an inaugural "San Diego Robotics Open House", and invite you to an evening of connecting “across silos” as one San Diego robotics ecosystem. This informal event is part reboot of SD-IEEE’s Robotics and Automation Society chapter, part robotics opportunities and bringing together Entrepreneurs/Professionals/Industry/Academia as one community. So be ready to learn what’s going on in town, tell your story, and/or recruit talent!  

Schedule

5:45 - Registration & Networking

6:15 - Ecosystem Discussion

7:00 - Mixer

7:30 - SDJUG Speaker: Nicolas Rigaud

9:30 - Meeting Ends, final announcements, tear down (optional After Party at Common Theory)

San Diego Robotics Open House is a great chance to mingle with each other and with executives of local robotics companies. The Ecosystem Discussion will begin with an Opportunity Shout Out, where companies/startups/individuals looking for talent or offering talent will have up to a minute to make their pitch. Next, we’ll go directly into a series of brief introductions from our hosts, guest companies, and student competitors (RoboSub Challenge July 2016)

• List of participating organization (or Executives):

• Chad Amonn, CEO / Co-Founder, Inova Drone

• Eric Patten, President/CEO, Ocean Aero

• Hansol Hong, CEO, Robolink

• Jeff Debrosse, CTO/Co-Founder, NXT Robotics

• Marius Buibas, Co-Founder, Accel Robotics

• Nick Morozovsky, Co-Founder, Accel Robotics

• Robert Rose, CEO, NXT Robotics

• Sandeep Pandya, President, NetraDyne, Inc

SDJUG Presents
Subject Title: The future of robotics

Speaker Name: Nicolas Rigaud 

Abstract:
Robots have been in our minds for ages. Our imagination has been fed by science fiction, movies, cartons. But where are the robots to be seen today? You might wonder.
At Aldebaran, we’ve been making robots for the last 10 years. Programmable humanoid robots. Social robots. Robots that don’t focus on performance but rather on interacting with people. We get the feeling they are the ultimate interface. But what are they useful for? How do they work? And more importantly: why should you pay attention to them?
In this presentation, we'll invite Pepper on stage to do some demos, we’ll discuss software, hardware, sensors and emotions, we’ll share our vision about the future of robotics, and as much as we can, we’ll try to answer all the questions you have about this new species that will soon take over the world.

Speaker Bio:
Nicolas Rigaud joined Aldebaran four years ago as a community manager, after spending 9 years in the media industry.
He is now developers advocate and manages relations with external developer communities. He’s strongly convinced that robots will change our lives in the years to come, and keep spreading the word all over the world.
He's been talking at a range of events around the world (JavaOne, Devoxx, JFokus) and was awarded JavaOne RockStar in 2015.

Company Bio:
Aldebaran designs and produces kindly and interactive humanoid robots.

events.name: Joint Meetup with Java User's Group

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
This month the Android Group will be having a joint meeting with the Java User's Group at their usual meeting spot at Resmed.  

In the first half of the meeting, Paul Webber will be reviewing his trip to the Java One 2016 conference and sharing what he learned there with us.  For the second half, Bill Wixted will be discussing his Android app "Network Explorer".  See below for abstracts and bios for this event.

Please note that the meeting location and start time for this event are different from our usual location and time.  Resmed is in the Kearny Mesa area (9001 Spectrum Center Blvd) and the meeting start time is 7:00 PM.

You can park (for free) in the Resmed parking structure.  Just walk into the main lobby and you'll see the meeting room just ahead.

Ryan Bradley and the great people at Integrated Associates will be sponsoring food and drink for this event.  Thanks Ryan!


Speaker: Paul Webber

Title: Javaone 2016 Recap

Abstract: Five days of the 2016 JavaOne conference condensed to 30 minutes or less! Plus I'll throw in the Java Community Process and JavaOne4Kids! Just a few slides about the conference with my commentary about the conference itself. I'll show some of the timelines for the major Java initiatives and end with a few references that you might find useful.

Speaker Bio: Paul has been involved the software industry for over 25 years programming in languages such as SmallTalk, C++, Java, and Android. He has worked in many domains in the San Diego area with a strong interest in Agile Development practices. He has been involved in several volunteer organizations such as the Boy Scouts of America, Botball and The League of Amazing Programmers; giving back to the community. Paul has been the President of the SDJUG since 2001 actively coordinating the monthly meetings. Currently he is working at ResMed, a company committed to changing lives with every breath by treating sleep disordered breathing.

Abstract: Bill Wixted will present an app that he recently developed for fun.
It's called Network Explorer. You can find it in the Google Play Store.
This is a version 1.0 so he'd appreciate any feedback you have.
Bill will talk about some of the pitfalls and challenges he ran into during development. He'll also discuss some of the design patterns he used and networking code he developed for it. Topics he will touch on:
• fragments, action bar, navigation drawer
• Wi-Fi network discovery
• Bluetooth device discovery
• Discovering devices connected to a Wi-Fi network
• Integrating ACRA and Google Analytics.

Speaker Bio: Bill has 30 years of experience in software development including the last 15 years as a software development manager for Quest Software and Dell Software. He has led software development teams of 5 to 12 engineers and has been responsible for the full software product lifecycle from initial concept to final delivery. He has experience with roadmap development , defining product requirements, developing technical specs, designing system architecture, and project management using Agile and Scrum methodologies.

At Dell Software, Bill most recently led the development of mobile app monitoring toolkits for Android and iOS. Bill has extensive experience in web site design, web site and mobile app performance monitoring, distributed systems, LAMP stack, Java, C++, Android, HTML, JavaScript and TCP/IP. Since leaving Dell this summer Bill has been freelancing as a consultant and working on his Network Explorer app.

events.name: SDJUG Cross Post: Java on Mobile : Write Once, Run on iOS and Android

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
See sdjug.org for more details. 6:30 food and drink; 7 pm start.
Speaker: Paul Anderson and Gail Anderson

Title: "Java on Mobile : Write Once, Run on iOS and Android"

Abstract: JavaFX 8 offers a rich set of visually appealing UI controls, a convenient property binding mechanism for event handling, and a powerful tool for layout and design. This session shows you how to develop mobile applications with Java and JavaFX and deploy them on IOS and Android devices, all from the same code base. The session begins with an overview of JavaFX UI controls and property binding techniques. After demonstrating an example JavaFX application with FXML, Scene Builder, and Gluon Maps, you’ll learn how to deploy the app on a mobile device (IOS or Android). You’ll also learn how to keep connected mobile devices updated when data in the cloud changes. This session includes several useful examples and shows how Java and JavaFX makes it easy to develop applications that target different mobile devices. This write once, run anywhere (WORA) platform uses an IDE plug in and library support from Gluon to create native applications.

Speaker Bios: Paul Anderson is the Director of Training and founding member of the Anderson Software Group. Paul is an experienced speaker and specializes in making the technical aspects of software engineering fun and understandable. Gail Anderson is the Director of Research and founding member of the Anderson Software Group. Gail enjoys researching and writing about leading-edge Java technologies. Paul and Gail are the authors of eight textbooks on software programming, including JavaFX Rich Client Programming on the NetBeans Platform.

Company Bio: Anderson Software Group, Inc. is a leading provider of training courses in Java, JavaFX, Python, C++, and other programming languages. For more information about Paul and Gail and the Anderson Software Group, visit www.asgteach.com.

events.name: January Meetup - Mobile Apps on AWS and Maps - the Original Big Data Problem

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
Hi Everyone!  It's time for our first meeting of 2017!

Note we have a new location. Proven Recruiting is hosting us now!  Many thanks to Kelly Feest for arranging the meeting place.  Here's the address:

9444 Waples St., San Diego, CA

Note: We were originally setup to be hosted at Qualcomm but there was a problem with the space so we've moved to the Proven Recruiting office!

Food & Drink Sponsor: Kelly Feest and Proven Recruiting are sponsoring this event!  

Schedule

5:30 doors open - networking and (hopefully) food/drink

6:00 Android group housekeeping

6:10 Rob Chohan on Maps

6:35 Rohan Deshpande on Mobile Apps using AWS

8:00ish - wrap up

Parking:  There's parking in the garage (no gates / no badging need) and also street parking around the perimeter of the campus.

Here's a map of the area. We will be in building AZ!

Presenters: We have 2 presenters for this meeting.

Building Secure and Scalable Mobile Applications on AWS

by Rohan Deshpande, Senior Engineer Amazon Web Services

Description: AWS Mobile Hub is a cloud platform for developers to "build, test, and monitor mobile apps" that leverage AWS services. AWS Mobile Hub lets you easily add and configure features for your mobile apps, including user authentication, data storage, APIs and backend logic, push notifications, intelligent bots, content delivery, and analytics. Whether you are creating a brand new mobile app or adding features to an existing app, AWS Mobile Hub lets you leverage the features, scalability, reliability, and low cost of AWS in minutes. AWS Mobile Hub walks you through feature selection and configuration, automatically provisions the AWS services required to power these features, and generates working apps for iOS and Android that use your provisioned services. 
 
You can then test your app on the same devices your customers use and run tests across a large selection of physical devices. Unlike emulators, physical devices provide a more accurate understanding of how users interact with your app by taking into account factors such as memory, CPU usage, location, and modifications done by manufactures and carriers to the firmware and software.

In this session, we will demo how to create a mobile app with AWS Mobile Hub and integrate the features with various AWS Services, and test the app using AWS Device Farm. 

Speaker Bio: Rohan Deshpande is a Senior Engineer with Amazon Web Services. He is the technical owner of the Amazon Mobile Push/SMS/Email channels, AWS Device Farm, Amazon Pinpoint, AWS Mobile Hub, and the AWS SDK for React Native. He is passionate about the mobile developer experience, automation, intelligent interfaces, and serverless cloud computing.

Maps — the original big data problem (literally).  Maps — the original data visualization solution.

by Rob Chohan, Mobile Architect, ePi Rational, Inc.

Summary: No matter how you describe a map, it is probably one of the top ten used apps on your mobile device. Consider how much land or square kilometers a paper map covers.  Add in a mobile device and GPS receiver, and a location that has no data signal and you have solid compelling product for traversing the back country with a mobile map.  The talk will focus around making a back country hiking map for iOS and Android based on US Forest Service maps that are freely available.  

This talk is about the power of maps for mobile.  Rob will discuss the data wrangling and image processing of making a map for mobile using open source technologies such as Mapbox, GDAL, GeoJSON, and WEBP. 

For a quick intro on the product check out: http://RobLabs.com/MtW

Speaker Bio: Rob Chohan loves maps.  Rob is taking his background in statistics, image processing, mobile imaging, and printing to create innovations in maps for mobile.  Rob currently works for ePi Rational, Inc., a San Diego based startup creating innovations in cartography, data visualization, mobile, and geoinformatics.  ePi focuses on 'data wrangling' to tell a story about a location. Rob has a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics and a Master of Science in Statistics, both from Oregon State University.   He has two patents related to calibration.

events.name: A/B Test Experimentation/Feature flagging

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
• What we'll do
Jesus Medrano from the Uber development team will be giving a presentation on some of the strategies the Uber development team uses.

Learn how shifting your development process to incorporate feature flagging and A/B testing can radically change the way to you develop on mobile. No longer do you need to create an emergency build to fix a bug in the latest release. Avoid merge/rebase hell by committing often even across multiple releases without adversely affecting users. Gain insights on what your users prefer without having hours of philosophical debates between product managers and engineering teams. Have the piece of mind to release something safely and be able to hit the undo button if it goes wrong.

events.name: A ROOM with a ViewModel - Part 1

group.name: GDG San Diego - Android Developers Group

events.description:
This is the first of three separate presentations designed to show a best practice way to store/access data stored in a local sqlite database.

Part 1 - Use the ROOM Sdk to replace old sqlite boiler plate code.
Part 2 - Access the sqlite data using LiveData.
Part 3 - Refactor the code to follow Google's recommended Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) architecture.

* Intermediate or greater skill level recommended.

** All code will be done in Kotlin - If you are new to Kotlin, see Joey's Intro to Kotlin presentation slides here: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1CXkcE5h5Cdxd3F8thbUDo8iymOspfn9eU8wlXjxvH0o/

Kelly Feest and Proven Recruiting will be sponsoring us with food and drink. Thank you Proven!
